newsitem.title: GERMANY: Jochimsen-EMU delay needed if criteria not met.
newsitem.headline: Jochimsen-EMU delay needed if criteria not met.

text.p: Bundesbank council member Raimut Jochimsen on Monday called for strict interpretation of the Maastricht criteria for European currency union membership.
The need for convergence to the criteria contained in the Maastricht treaty for membership of EMU was greater than the need for a timely start, Jochimsen said at a meeting in Wuppertal.
He said that it was gradually looking more likely that it would not be possible to have a timely start and meet the convergence criteria at the same time.
"It is not a terrible thing to delay it if (efforts to meet the criteria) are not enough," Jochimsen said.
Meanwhile, a leading member of Chancellor Kohl's Christian Democrats (CDU) called on Monday for a timely start to EMU on January 1 1999.

"The most important thing is that people have the necessary trust in the stability of currency union," Wolfgang Schaeuble, CDU parliamentary leader, said in the advance text of a television interview to be broadcast later this evening.

In the same edition of the EURO konkret programme, Wolfgang Franz, a member of the Council of Economic Advisors dubbed Germany's "Five Wise Men", called for a generous interpretation of the Maastricht treaty guidelines.
"Currency union is an historical achievement, which should not be allowed to fail because of a tenth of a percentage point," Franz said.
